items.content_html:
Summary

Chromium adds .avif to permitted Web share file extension.
This PR adds .avif to Navigator.share() shareable file types.

Motivation

A website might like their users to be able to share their pictures and other files through social media, email, chat, etc.
.avif showed better compression efficiency and better detail preservation than JPEG.
In this regard, adding avif to web share will helpful to user and spread the use of avif.

Supporting details

Related issues

https://crbug.com/1190122

Metadata

  • Adds a new document
  • Rewrites (or significantly expands) a document
  • Fixes a typo, bug, or other error
items.title: Add .avif to Navigator.share() shareable file types.

items.content_html:
Summary

Added a case that affects the containing block in chromium browsers.

Motivation

Spent a lot of time debugging a weird containing-block case, and it was caused by an ancestor having the backdrop-filter property (in chromium). Saw that it wasn't documented, so thought it would be helpful for others.

This PRâ€¦

items.title: Add case that affects identifying containing block

items.content_html:
When considering inline elements their margin only is respected horizontally and not vertically.
The corrections were aimed at that mistake of saying that vertical margins are respected and also
that padding has restrictions which is not the case because all 4 paddings are respected although
they only cause displacement of elements horizontally.

Summary

Correct margin and padding mix up when considering their effects on inline elements

Motivation

The change helps to make the tutorial correct and to give readers the theoretical box model knowledge that matches the browser rendering.

Supporting details

Related issues

Metadata

  • Adds a new document
  • Rewrites (or significantly expands) a document
  • Fixes a typo, bug, or other error
items.title: Correct mix up between margins and paddings

items.content_html:
Summary

made sections more consistent across the Learning HTML and Learning CSS Modules.

  • naming of the sections
  • adding missing sections that would normally always be present (e.g. article summaries)
  • adapting (text) content if necessary
  • catching some typos
  • making "In this module" sections uniform
    • there was a discussion #13781 where linking to the current page is giving a flaw and it shoudln't be done
    • but due to the fact that it was done like this almost everywhere - i also adapted it like this in a few places
    • i thought that would make it easier to fix the problem overall and result in fewer edge cases.

i would do the same for the other modules (e.g. Learn JavaScript) in further PRs when I continue to learn trough the modules (if desired of course).

Motivation

To keep things consistent.

Related issues

Fixes #13671

items.content_html:
Summary

I added OKLab color functions to CSS Functional Notation.

Motivation

They are part of CSS Color Modules 4.

Adding them to this list will fix Stylelint function-no-unknown since Stylelint uses this document as a source of all valid CSS function names.

Supporting details

Safari TP should support these functions.

items.content_html:
Summary

In Express Tutorial Part 3: Using a Database article, there's an erroneous code snippet:

var mongoose = require('mongoose')
  , Schema = mongoose.Schema
  
// other code

This pull request fixes it like so:

var mongoose = require('mongoose');

var Schema = mongoose.Schema;
  
// other code

Motivation

There is an erroneous code snippet.

Supporting details

n/a

Related issues

n/a

items.content_html:
Adding some improvement to example of https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/fetch#examples, and linking to other section that has the example.
Related to #14858 (comment)

Summary

This change improve the example of the fetch() page, so new comer/veteran that move from XHR to fetch can get glimps of how to use fetch fast without moving between pages.

Motivation

Adding more detail for example, and linking to other resource that MDN already has, so people can easily learn by example and simplify user to find the other document that support the example.

For some section that I add using headings of the example with long names, to make sure Search Engine easily index fetch() page with common search term, so MDN will end up at top of the list while people using the common search term.(in theory)

Supporting details

None

Related issues

Fixes #14858

Bumps actions/setup-node from 3.1.0 to 3.1.1.

Sourced from actions/setup-node's releases.

Update actions/cache version to 2.0.2

In scope of this release we updated actions/cache package as the new version contains fixes related to GHES 3.5 (actions/setup-node#460)

Commits
  • 56337c4 Updated @â€‹actions/cache (#460)
  • 76d3665 Convert CONDUCT to CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md (#391)
  • See full diff in compare view

Dependabot will resolve any conflicts with this PR as long as you don't alter it yourself. You can also trigger a rebase manually by commenting @dependabot rebase.

Dependabot commands and options

You can trigger Dependabot actions by commenting on this PR:

  • @dependabot rebase will rebase this PR
  • @dependabot recreate will recreate this PR, overwriting any edits that have been made to it
  • @dependabot merge will merge this PR after your CI passes on it
  • @dependabot squash and merge will squash and merge this PR after your CI passes on it
  • @dependabot cancel merge will cancel a previously requested merge and block automerging
  • @dependabot reopen will reopen this PR if it is closed
  • @dependabot close will close this PR and stop Dependabot recreating it. You can achieve the same result by closing it manually
  • @dependabot ignore this major version will close this PR and stop Dependabot creating any more for this major version (unless you reopen the PR or upgrade to it yourself)
  • @dependabot ignore this minor version will close this PR and stop Dependabot creating any more for this minor version (unless you reopen the PR or upgrade to it yourself)
  • @dependabot ignore this dependency will close this PR and stop Dependabot creating any more for this dependency (unless you reopen the PR or upgrade to it yourself)
items.title: Bump actions/setup-node from 3.1.0 to 3.1.1

items.content_html:
FF100 adds support for AbortSignal.timeout() in https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1753309

This adds docs for timeout, and also updates the AbortSignal parent with more examples showing how it is used. Also important, showing the limits.

Specifically the timeout is static method that returns a self aborting AbortSignal. You can't abort this yourself because it isn't associated with a controller. You also can't plug multiple signals into abort. So to do both manual and timeout abort at the same time you need to use a different approach. I decided that should be in the AbortSignal doc and not elsewhere.

Note that the examples provided are pretty basic, and draw on what is provided in the explainer.

This is in draft because I'm waiting on some confirmations in https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1753309#c13
items.title: FF100 Add AbortSignal.timeout() static method

items.content_html:
This is not quite ready to merge. I have made a small change to test a fix and will roll it out further if the approach is "approved".

The HTML global attributes page uses this syntax

- [{{HTMLAttrDef("accesskey")}}](/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Global_attributes/accesskey)

The intent appears to have been to create an in page anchor using HTMLAttrDef and then a link to the more detailed page (this makes sense because it allows the global attributes to contain links to all attributes, then drill down for more detail).

However the link to the detail page is being ignored. I have modified to remove the macro so that an explicit anchor can be created:

- <a id="attr-accesskey"></a>[`accesskey`](/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Global_attributes/accesskey)

This is what I do in other markdown, but I haven't seen this before in this doc set, which is why I ask. If this is OK I will roll out across the page. Otherwise, what is the right approach here?
items.title: HTML global attribute linking
